metadata.case_name: Income-tax Officers v. Union of India & Ors.

facts.text: Before Sept. 29, 1944, conditions of service and pay-scales of Income tax officers were different in different Provinces.
By letter dated 23-3-43, existing grade of Asstt. Income Tax officers designated as Income tax officers, Grade II, pending constitution of Class I and Class II Service.

Re-organisation scheme launched by letter dated 29-9-44 creating Central Service Class I and Class II with specific posts: Class I - Commissioners (87 perm +1 temp), Asst Commissioners (360 perm +18 temp), ITO Grade I (125 perm +26 temp), ITO Grade II (125 perm +63 temp); Class II - ITO Grade III (9 perm +74 temp).
Recruitment to ITO Grade I Class I by selection from Grade II and existing Grade I Class II.
Recruitment to ITO Grade II Class I: 80% direct via Indian Audit and Accounts etc. Examination, 20% promotion from Grade III Class II; surplus to direct.
Para 3: New classification applies to officers recruited under new scheme including selected from existing Grade I Class II; non-selected remain Class II.
Government wrote to Federal Public Service Commission on 29-9-1944 to approve 100 officers for Class I Grade I and recruit 10 for Grade II via Oct 1944 exam.
On 26-5-1945, rules framed for recruitment to ITO Class I Grade II: by competitive exam (Part II), promotion from Grade III Class II (Part III); Govt determines methods and numbers.
Respondents 31 to 39 appointed as ITO Class I Grade II in 1945.
On 8-11-1945, Govt proposed to continue promotions to Grade II Class I from pre-existing Class II Grade I for next 2-3 years outside 20% limit.
Federal Public Service Commission replied 23-5-46 no objection to exceptional promotions from pre-existing Class II Grade I.
Respondents 11 and 25 appointed in 1946 (respondent 25 original date 1-6-1947).
All petitioners confirmed as Asst Commissioners in 1959; respondents 6-39 also confirmed Asst Commissioners, most earlier.
Petitioners appointed as ITO Class I Grade II in 1946 or 1947 except some.
Respondents 6-10, 26,27,28 appointed in 1947.
On 3-1-1947, Govt forwarded names for Class I Grades I and II to FPSC, noting temporary posts.
Petitioners completed probation in 1949, confirmed 1949-1950 except petitioner 9 on 22-12-1951; most respondents confirmed 1946-1948.
29-4-1949 Dept Promotion Committee agreed promotions from 1-8-1948 for 1944 recruits, affecting respondents 12-24,29,30.
14-6-49 representations by direct recruits including some petitioners against proposed Seniority Rules.
9-9-1949 Seniority Rules framed; seniority list as on 1-1-1950 circulated 24-1-1950, representations on data till 28-2-1950, not on principles.
Feb 1949: 51 old Class II Grade I officers to be finally selected or reverted.
18-10-1951: Modified quota to 66-2/3% direct, 33-1/3% promotion for 5 years.
1-1-1952 all petitioners promoted and confirmed as ITO Class I Grade I.
Feb 1952 Committee revised seniority rules; decided to treat some DPC as Sept 1948, making respondents 12-24,29,30 senior to 1945 direct recruits.
Seniority rules variations: 1949, 1950 (with proviso), 1952 (promotees before next DPC senior to direct recruits of that year and 3 previous).
1-8-53 revised seniority list issued.
1955-1956 petitioners promoted as Asst Commissioners.
Representations continued 1954-1959, interview with Finance Minister 1960.
25-4-62 Jaisinghani filed writ in High Court, judgment 11-3-64, appeal to SC.
22-2-67 SC judgment in Jaisinghani appeal and Joshi writ.
Present writ petition filed July 1967.

legal_issues.text: Whether appointments of respondents 6-39 to Class I Grade II were irregular/illegal outside quota and discriminatory seniority rules infringe Arts. 14 and 16.
Whether pre-Constitution acts can be challenged under Arts. 14 and 16.
Whether petition barred by gross delay.
Whether relief claimed against Jaisinghani decision.

petitioner_arguments.text: Government breached rules by appointing respondents 6-39 outside quota for recruitment to service; illegal absorption and preferential seniority in Class I Grade II and promotions via discriminatory rules hostile to direct recruits.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S. G. Jaisinghani v. Union of India; Arts. 14, 16

petitioner_arguments.text: Seniority should be post-dated to when appointed had quota been followed.
No inordinate delay; facts known in 1961.

respondent_arguments.text: Challenged acts happened before Constitution; cannot be challenged under Arts. 14, 16.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Pannalal Binjrai v. Union of India; Keshavan Madhava Menon v. State of Bombay
Tilokchand Motichand; Laxmanappa v. Union of India
S. G. Jaisinghani v. Union of India

respondent_arguments.text: Recruitment included selection from existing Class II Grade I as direct recruitment.

court_reasoning.text: Appointments pre-Constitution; no retrospective effect of Arts. 14,16; cannot challenge pre-26-1-1950 acts like appointments, 1950 seniority list, 1949/50 rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Constitution has no retrospective operation; Shanti Sarup distinguished.

court_reasoning.text: 1952 rules and 1953 list post-Constitution but petition after 15 years inordinate delay; no relief under Art.32 for stale claims.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Delay fatal; unjust to disturb accrued rights after years.

court_reasoning.text: Petitioners not competent to challenge appointment validity: pre-Constitution, delay, time-barred, Jaisinghani protects confirmed Asst Commissioners.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Treat appointments valid but seniority not challengeable now.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide merits due to preliminary objections.

holdings.text: Pre-Constitution appointments and seniority not challengeable under Arts.14,16.
Art.32 petition not maintainable after inordinate delay without explanation.
Petition dismissed; no interference with appointments/promotions of 1945-1950.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. G. Jaisinghani v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Principle on service rules; protects confirmed Asst Commissioners; statutory nature of rules.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pannalal Binjrai v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: No retrospective effect of Art.13; pre-Constitution valid acts not challengeable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Keshavan Madhava Menon v. State of Bombay
Shanti Sarup v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Limited to continuing post-Constitution deprivation; not applicable here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sri Jagadguru Nari Basava Rajendra Swami v. Commissioner of Hindu Religious Charitable Endowments
precedents_cited.relevance: Observations in Shanti Sarup not unqualified; no retrospective fundamental rights.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kuru Datta Sharma v. State of Bihar
Tilokchand Motichand v. H. B. Munshi
precedents_cited.relevance: Delay can be fatal under Art.32.

precedents_cited.case_name: Laxmanappa Hanumantappa Jamkhandi v. Union of India

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition under 32 for enforcement of 14,16; no retrospective effect.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Officers Class I, Grade II Service Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Recruitment and seniority determination; some held statutory.

outcome.summary: Writ petition dismissed on preliminary grounds: challenged acts pre-Constitution not violative of Arts.14,16 retrospectively, and inordinate delay of 15+ years bars relief under Art.32; no interference with appointments, seniority, promotions of respondents.

key_quotes.text: "It is settled that Art. 13 of the Constitution has no retrospective effect and if... any action was taken before the commencement... such action cannot be challenged..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on no retrospective challenge to pre-Constitution acts.

key_quotes.text: "This Court... cannot discard all principles and grant relief in petitions filed after inordinate delay. We... must administer justice in accordance with law and principles of equity, justice and good conscience."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justification for dismissing on delay grounds.

key_quotes.text: "Each person ought to be entitled to sit back and consider that his appointment and promotion effected a long time ago would not be set aside after the lapse of a number of years."
key_quotes.speaker: court
